elements.content: The complexes [Cs(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (4), [Rb(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (5), [Cs(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (6), [Rb(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (7), [K(CTV)(DMF)]2(OH)(H2O)(CB11H12) (8), and [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9) (CTV = cyclotriveratrylene) all form as crystalline inclusion complexes from N,N‘-dimethylformamide (=DMF) solutions. The overall structures of complexes 4−9 are strikingly similar, forming extended coordinate and hydrogen-bonding interactions, and all feature intracavity complexation of DMF by CTV and [CB11H12]- or C2B10H12 as channel-type guest molecules. A pseudopolymorph of 9 can be formed from 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol solution.

The overall structures of these compounds are strikingly similar, forming extended coordinate and hydrogen-bonding interactions, and all feature intracavity complexation of DMF by CTV and [CB11H12]- or C2B10H12 as channel-type guest molecules.

Introduction

Cyclotriveratrylene (=CTV; 1) is a rigid cyclic molecule with a curved-bowl shape similar to the cone conformation of many calixarenes, albeit with a somewhat shallower cavity. The trigonal arrangements of dimethoxy moieties within CTV are potential hydrogen bond acceptor groups or metal coordination sites. In this context we have recently shown that CTV can be used as a crystal engineering tecton through its incorporation into infinite hydrogen-bonded arrays or group 1 coordination polymers with Na+ or K+. CTV is a potential host molecule; however, despite the presence of a cavity, examples of intracavity guest complexation by CTV are rare, and they usually involve large inorganic or organometallic guest molecules such as fullerenes, 1,2-dicarbadodecaborane(12) (=o-carborane), and [FeCp(C6H5R)]+. Smaller organic solvent molecules are not usually bound as intracavity guests; instead, they form solid-state lattice channel-type structures with the organic guest molecules situated in spaces created by the CTV packing motif. Many common solvents, including DMF, are reported to not form a complex with CTV. It is notable that bi- and trimetallic CTV complexes, involving CTV acting as a π-ligand for transition metals, can incorporate anionic guest molecules such as BF4 - and ReO4 -.

Introduction

Cyclotriveratrylene (=CTV; 1) is a rigid cyclic molecule with a curved-bowl shape similar to the cone conformation of many calixarenes, albeit with a somewhat shallower cavity. The trigonal arrangements of dimethoxy moieties within CTV are potential hydrogen bond acceptor groups or metal coordination sites. In this context we have recently shown that CTV can be used as a crystal engineering tecton through its incorporation into infinite hydrogen-bonded arrays or group 1 coordination polymers with Na+ or K+. CTV is a potential host molecule; however, despite the presence of a cavity, examples of intracavity guest complexation by CTV are rare, and they usually involve large inorganic or organometallic guest molecules such as fullerenes, 1,2-dicarbadodecaborane(12) (=o-carborane), and [FeCp(C6H5R)]+. Smaller organic solvent molecules are not usually bound as intracavity guests; instead, they form solid-state lattice channel-type structures with the organic guest molecules situated in spaces created by the CTV packing motif. Many common solvents, including DMF, are reported to not form a complex with CTV. It is notable that bi- and trimetallic CTV complexes, involving CTV acting as a π-ligand for transition metals, can incorporate anionic guest molecules such as BF4 - and ReO4 -.

elements.content: Incorporating CTV into crystal engineering type networks appears to alter its inclusion behavior, with, for instance, dimethylformamide (=DMF) or 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol included as intracavity guest molecules in the complexes [Na(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](o-carborane), [K(OH)(CTV)(DMF)]2(o-carborane), and [Na(CTV)][Co(C2B9H11)2](CF3CH2OH)0.25. All of these complexes feature two-dimensional infinite hydrogen-bonded arrays and/or coordination polymers involving CTV, M+, and/or water and hydroxide. Their other common feature is the presence of o-carborane or a carborane-based anion within the crystal lattice. The neutral icosahedral cluster molecule o-carborane (C2B10H12) can be present in a diverse range of supramolecular systems and can act as a source of acidic hydrogens for hydrogen-bonding interactions and/or as a large spherical guest molecule. The role of the carborane in the above Na+ and K+ complexes is unclear.

elements.content: This present study investigates whether the larger alkali metals Rb+ and Cs+ can also be ligated by CTV in the presence of o-carborane and DMF and what effect this may have on the crystalline inclusion behavior. The function of the icosahedral moiety in these complexes is further elucidated by replacing o-carborane with an anionic carborane, namely [CB11H12]-, which has similar steric features but entirely different electrostatic properties. There are a number of anionic carboranes known; one of the closest to o-carborane in terms of size and symmetry is the aforementioned icosahedral [CB11H12]-, available commercially as the Cs+ salt 3. [CB11H12]- is a weakly coordinating anion, although it has been shown to form close interactions with Ag+ via Ag−H−B interactions.

elements.content: Synthesis. [Cs(CTV) 2 (OH)(H 2 O) 2 (DMF) 2 ](C 2 B 10 H 12 ) (4) and [Rb(CTV) 2 (OH)(H 2 O) 2 (DMF) 2 ](C 2 B 10 H 12 ) (5). Equimolar quantities of CTV and o-carborane (∼5 mg scale) were dissolved separately in hot DMF and mixed and an excess of 0.1 M aqueous MOH (0.1 mL; M = Cs, Rb) added. The solutions were cooled and allowed to stand. Colorless prismatic crystals of [Cs(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (4) or [Rb(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (5) appeared after 1 week. The complexes lose solvent on prolonged exposure to the atmosphere.

elements.content: Crystal Structure Determinations. Details of data collections and structure refinements for 4−6 and 8−10 are given in Table . Only the unit cell parameters of complex 7 are reported herein, although full details of the structure are available as Supporting Information. All crystals were mounted on a glass capillary under oil, and data were collected at 123(1) K on an Enraf-Nonius KappaCCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Data were corrected for Lorentzian and polarization effects but not absorption. Structures were solved with SHELXS-97 and refined by full-matrix least squares on F 2 using SHELXL-97. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All C−H and B−H hydrogens were included at geometrically estimated positions. Additional details are outlined below.

[Cs(CTV) 2 (OH)(H 2 O) 2 (DMF) 2 ](C 2 B 10 H 12 ) (4) . The structure was solved by a Patterson map and partial structure expansion. The carborane was modeled as disordered with four vertexes having some C character. The heavy-atom position was modeled as 50% Cs and 50% O, consistent with the disorder model adopted for [Cs(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (6) (see below). One O position was of mixed water/hydroxide character. The DMF molecule showed a symmetry-imposed 2-fold disorder, and the O was given 50% occupancy.

One O position was of mixed water/hydroxide character. The DMF molecule showed a symmetry-imposed 2-fold disorder, and the O was given 50% occupancy.

elements.content:
[Rb(CTV) 2 (OH)(H 2 O) 2 (DMF) 2 ](C 2 B 10 H 12 ) (5). This compound is isostructural with 4 and was treated the same.

[Cs(CTV) 2 (H 2 O) 3 (DMF) 2 ](CB 11 H 12 ) (6). The structure was solved by a Patterson map and partial structure expansion. The carborane anion was modeled as completely disordered, with each vertex given 1/12th C character. There was one heavy-atom position which was modeled as 50% Cs and 50% O (of a water) on the basis of the disorder model shown in Scheme , where there are two coordinated water molecules and one hydrogen-bonded water. The two Cs/O positions shown in Scheme are crystallographically equivalent. The crystallographic and chemical evidence for this model includes the following:  unacceptable displacement parameters and overall scale factor for a 100% Cs assignment, charge balance considerations, the fact that the heavy position is unlikely to be unoccupied 50% of the time, direct parallels between this model and the coordinate and hydrogen-bonding interactions seen in the complexes [Na(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](o-carborane)3 and [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9), and the fact that the observed Cs/OH2−OH2 bond length of 2.833(5) Å is short. The structure solution in space group P1 gave the same structural features, indicating that the Cs/O disorder is not imposed by crystal symmetry. The DMF showed a disorder similar to that of 4.

elements.content: Crystalline complexes were obtained from the slow evaporation of equimolar mixtures of CTV (1) and o-carborane (2) in DMF with an excess of aqueous MOH (M = alkali metal), as summarized in Scheme . The Na+ and K+ complexes have been previously reported, and isostructural complexes involving [CB11H12]- are described later in this paper. The Cs+ and Rb+ complexes [Cs(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (4) and [Rb(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (5) are isostructural, crystallizing in a monoclinic cell (Table ), and the structures were solved in space group C2/m from X-ray data collected at low temperatures. Only the Cs+ complex is discussed in detail below.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystalline complexes were obtained from the slow evaporation of equimolar mixtures of CTV (1) and o-carborane (2) in DMF with an excess of aqueous MOH (M = alkali metal), as summarized in Scheme . The Na+ and K+ complexes have been previously reported, and isostructural complexes involving [CB11H12]- are described later in this paper. The Cs+ and Rb+ complexes [Cs(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (4) and [Rb(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (5) are isostructural, crystallizing in a monoclinic cell (Table ), and the structures were solved in space group C2/m  from X-ray data collected at low temperatures. Only the Cs+ complex is discussed in detail below.

<fig fig-type="scheme" id="cg000004fh00002" orientation="portrait" position="float">
<label>2</label>
<graphic orientation="portrait" position="float" xlink:href="cg000004fh00002.tif"></graphic>
</fig>

The structure is complicated, with many levels of supramolecular interaction, including coordinate bonding, hydrogen bonding, π stacking, and intracavity and channel type host−guest interactions. The Cs+ center is coordinated by six oxygen donors in a highly distorted octahedral geometry, with two chelating CTV ligands, bonding through their dimethoxy moieties (Cs−O distances 3.123(4) and 2.888(4) Å) and two cis symmetry equivalent ligands of mixed water and hydroxide character (Cs−O distance 2.817(5) Å). One methyl carbon of each CTV is also in close contact with the metal at a Cs−C distance of 3.638(6) Å. The heavy-atom positions within the crystal structure are disordered with 50% Cs and 50% O character, and the disorder model adopted is shown in Scheme (see Experimental Section). This involves the mixed hydroxide/water ligands hydrogen bonding to another water molecule which is in turn hydrogen-bonded to two CTV ligands. The apparent bridging nature of the hydroxide/water ligands in Figures and actually represents an averaging of Cs−(OH)(H2O)···(H2O) and (H2O)···(OH)(H2O)−Cs arrangements, where ··· designates hydrogen bonding.

One methyl carbon of each CTV is also in close contact with the metal at a Cs-C distance of 3.638(6) Å. The heavy-atom positions within the crystal structure are disordered with 50% Cs and 50% O character, and the disorder model adopted is shown in Scheme  (see Experimental Section). This involves the mixed hydroxide/water ligands hydrogen bonding to another water molecule which is in turn hydrogen-bonded to two CTV ligands. The apparent bridging nature of the hydroxide/water ligands in Figures  and  actually represents an averaging of Cs-(OH)(H2O)⋅⋅⋅(H2O) and (H2O)⋅⋅⋅(OH)(H2O)-Cs arrangements, where ⋅⋅⋅ designates hydrogen bonding.

elements.content: Each CTV ligand bridges between two disordered Cs/O−(OH)(H2O)−Cs/O cores through two of its dimethoxy groups to create the chain structure highlighted in Figure . The third dimethoxy group of each CTV is at hydrogen bonding distances to the coordinated hydroxide/water ligands of an adjacent chain (O···O separation 2.86 Å), forming a two-dimensional sheet structure shown in projection in Figure . There are two tiers of coplanar CTV molecules, each with their CTV cavities pointing inward but in inverted orientations. Each CTV within the network acts as a host molecule for one molecule of guest DMF as a perched structure in which the DMF is positioned directly above one phenyl group of the CTV with the DMF nitrogen roughly above the center of the aromatic ring at a N···centroid separation of 3.59 Å.

elements.content: The two-dimensional networks stack together within the crystal lattice through π−π interactions. Each CTV forms three such interactions through each of its phenyl rings to another CTV of an adjacent network. The CTV phenyl rings π stack in a coplanar but slightly slipped fashion with aromatic centroid···centroid separations of 3.54, 3.54, and 3.61 Å. The packing of the networks is such that methyl-lined cavities are formed. The carborane guest molecules are located within these hydrophobic channels with a closest carborane C/B to CTV methyl distance of 3.92 Å (Figure ). The complex [Rb(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (5) is isostructural with 4 and was given the same disorder model. Rb−O bond lengths were 2.791(2) and 3.056(2) Å to CTV (closest Rb−C distance 3.553(3) Å) and 2.780(2) Å to the mixed water/hydroxide ligand.

elements.content: The arrangement of non-hydrogen atomic positions within [Cs(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (4) and the isostructural [Rb(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](C2B10H12) (5) is the same as that of the previously reported K+ complex [K(OH)(CTV)(DMF)]2(C2B10H12) with unit cell parameters a = 19.3270(3) Å, b = 14.8709(2) Å, c = 12.5698(1) Å, and β = 116.021(1)°. In [K(OH)(CTV)(DMF)]2(C2B10H12), however, the K+ sites are fully ordered and a genuine K−μ-(OH)2−K bridge is observed within a −K−μ-(OH)2−K−μ-(CTV)2−K−μ-(OH)2−K− coordinate chain. The M−(OH)(H2O)···(H2O) structural motif of complexes 4 and 5 has been previously seen in the analogous Na+ complex [Na(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](o-carborane), where ···(OH)(H2O)Na−(CTV)2···(H2O)···(OH)(H2O)Na(CTV)2··· coordination and a hydrogen-bonded chain is observed, and is also found for the carborane anion containing complex [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9).

elements.content: Mixing equimolar quantities of cesium carborane (3) and CTV (1) in DMF solution gave the crystalline complex [Cs(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (6) (Scheme ). Complex 6 crystallizes in a monoclinic cell similar to that of 4 (Table ), although the cell volume is ∼28 Å3 greater for 6 than for 4. The structure was solved in space group C2/m from X-ray data collected at low temperatures.

elements.content: Surprisingly, the use of a carborane with electrostatic properties entirely different from those of the neutral o-carborane has little overall effect on the structure of the complex obtained. Despite being composed of different chemical substituents, the structures of complexes 6 and 4 are essentially the same, with complex 6 containing the carborane anion [CB11H12]- in place of o-carborane and two water molecules instead of mixed water/hydroxide ligands to complete the Cs+ coordination sphere (Figure ). The inclusion behavior is identical with that of 4, with DMF as an intracavity guest molecule and the carborane anion occupying the hydrophobic methyl-lined cavities at a closest carborane C/B to CTV methyl separation of 3.88 Å. The larger cell volume can be attributed to the slightly larger size of the carborane anion (shortest para vertex···vertex distance 3.36 Å) compared to o-carborane (shortest para vertex···vertex distance 3.11 Å, from the crystal structure of 4). There are no other significant differences in bond lengths and intermolecular distances between 4 and 6.

The structure is analogous with that of the o-carborane-containing 4, with the disordered Cs/O−(H2O)2−Cs/O an average of Cs−(H2O)2···(H2O) and (H2O)···(H2O)2−Cs (see Scheme ).

elements.content: The disordered nature of the Cs+ cation in complexes 4 and 6 suggests that the large Cs+ is not a well-matched metal for CTV coordination. This is borne out by addition of aqueous MOH (M = Rb, K, Na) to DMF solutions of CTV (1) and cesium carborane (3), which leads to the preferential complexation of Rb+, K+, or Na+ over Cs+ by CTV in the complexes [Rb(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (7), [K(CTV)(DMF)]2(OH)(H2O)(CB11H12) (8), and [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9) (Scheme ). The presence of the smaller alkali-metal cations and absence of Cs+ in complexes 7−9 was confirmed by microprobe analysis, and their crystal structures were determined from X-ray data collected at low temperatures. In each case, the crystal structure is isostructural with that found for o-carborane and the corresponding alkali-metal hydroxide (Scheme ).

elements.content: While having a similar CTV packing motif to the other structures discussed herein, the coordination behaviors of the metal in the K+-containing complexes [K(OH)(CTV)(DMF)]2(C2B11H12)3 and [K(CTV)(DMF)]2(OH)(H2O)(CB11H12) (8) are somewhat different. In [K(OH)(CTV)(DMF)]2(C2B11H12) a coordinate chain is formed, through bis μ-(OH) and bis μ-(CTV) linkages. An analogous chain is formed in complex 8; however, here the bridging O ligand has mixed hydroxide/water character due to charge balance considerations (K−O distance 2.716(3) Å; Figure ). This bridging ligand also acts as a hydrogen-bond donor, with interactions to the uncoordinated dimethoxy moieties of CTV molecules from adjacent, identical chains (O···O separation 2.98 Å) to form the familiar 2D sheet structure. The bridging and chelating CTV ligands are at K−O bond lengths of 2.734(2) and 3.015(2) Å.

elements.content: The complex [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9) crystallizes in a monoclinic cell of approximately double the volume seen for complexes 4−8. The structure was solved in space group C2/c. Despite the larger cell, the CTV packing motif of 9 is once more the same as that for the other complexes, with a two-dimensional sheet structure formed by a combination of coordinate and hydrogen-bonding interactions.

elements.content: Whereas the K+ complex 8 featured a coordinate chain, and the Rb+- and Cs+-containing complexes were modeled with a disordered M−(H2O)2···(H2O) or M−(OH)(H2O)···(H2O) structure, complex 9 features an ordered M−(H2O)2···(H2O) arrangement. The two-dimensional sheet structure formed by CTV, Na+, and water is shown in Figure . Each Na+ center is six-coordinate, with two chelating CTV ligands (Na−O distances 2.556(2) and 2.689(2) Å) and two cis terminal water ligands at an Na−OH2 bond length of 2.397(4) Å. The terminal water ligands act as hydrogen bond donors, with both coordinated waters hydrogen bonding to the same additional molecule of water (O···O separation 2.80 Å), as well as each donating to the dimethoxy groups of different, adjacent CTV molecules (O···O separations 2.93, 3.16 Å). The hydrogen-bonded water molecule also acts as a hydrogen bond donor, interacting with the dimethoxy groups of two equivalent CTV molecules in a bifurcated manner (O···O distances of 2.86 and 3.13 Å). Each CTV molecule coordinates to one Na+ and hydrogen-bonds to one coordinated water (from an adjacent Na+ center) and one noncoordinated water molecule.

elements.content: Every CTV molecule within the lattice acts as a host for one molecule of guest DMF. The extended coordinate and hydrogen-bonded networks pack together through π−π stacking (centroid separations 3.62, 3.66, and 3.71 Å) in such a manner that methyl-lined cavities are formed which contain the carborane anion [CB11H12]- (Figure ). The structure of [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9) is directly analogous to that of the previously reported o-carborane complex [Na(CTV)2(OH)(H2O)2(DMF)2](o-carborane).

elements.content: Finally, mixing CTV (1) and cesium carborane (3) in 1:1 proportions in 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol instead of DMF gives a small amount of an Na+-containing crystalline product, [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(CF3CH2OH)2](CB11H12) (10). The source of the Na+ is likely to be the glassware. Complex 10 can be made deliberately in higher yield by addition of NaOH to a solution of 1 and 3 in 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol. The low-temperature X-ray structure was determined in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The complex is a pseudopolymorph of [Na(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (9):  that is, they differ only in the nature of the included solvent molecules. Aside from the solvent, 9 and 10 are isostructural. Like the guest DMF in 9, the 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol forms a perched intracavity host−guest assembly with CTV, and shows a 2-fold disorder (Figure ).

elements.content: The bowl-shaped host molecule CTV can act as a ligand for most alkali metals and can be incorporated into alkali-metal-based coordination and hydrogen-bonded polymers. This leads to unusual host−guest behavior with the small organic molecule DMF or 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol present as an intracavity guest and a carborane confined within cavities created by the packing motif. The complexes reported herein and in previous publications3 all have similar structures despite the complexation of metals of vastly different ionic radii. The identity of the carborane, whether it be the neutral carborane C2B10H12 or the anionic [CB11H12]-, has no effect on the structural or inclusion chemistry, which indicates that the role of the carborane in the formation of these complexes is likely to be steric, perhaps templating the packing of the extended networks.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

The bowl-shaped host molecule CTV can act as a ligand for most alkali metals and can be incorporated  into alkali-metal-based coordination and hydrogen-bonded polymers. This leads to unusual host-guest behavior with the small organic molecule DMF or 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol present as an intracavity guest and a carborane confined within cavities created by the packing motif. The complexes reported herein and in previous publications3 all have similar structures despite the complexation of metals of vastly different ionic radii. The identity of the carborane, whether it be the neutral carborane C2B10H12 or the anionic [CB11H12]-, has no effect on the structural or inclusion chemistry, which indicates that the role of the carborane in the formation of these complexes is likely to be steric, perhaps templating the packing of the extended networks.

cln_elements.content:
[Cs(CTV) 2 (H 2 O) 3 (DMF) 2 ](CB 11 H 12 ) (6 ). CTV (3.3 mg, 0.007 mmol) and cesium carborane (1.6 mg, 0.006 mmol) were dissolved separately in hot DMF, and the solution was allowed to stand. Colorless prismatic crystals of [Cs(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (6) appeared after 1 week, which lose solvent on standing.

[Na(CTV) 2 (H 2 O) 3 (CF 3 CH 2 OH) 2 ](CB 11 H 12 ) (10). CTV (5.8, 0.013 mmol) and cesium carborane (1.6 mg, 0.006 mmol) were dissolved separately in hot 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol and mixed, and an excess of 0.1 M aqueous NaOH (0.1 mL) was added. The solution was cooled and allowed to stand. Colorless prismatic crystals of Na(CTV)2(DMF)2(H2O)3(CF3CH2OH) (10) appeared after 1 day, which lose solvent on standing.

Colorless prismatic crystals of [Cs(CTV)2(H2O)3(DMF)2](CB11H12) (6) appeared after 1 week, which lose solvent on standing. 

 [Na(CTV)  2  (H  2  O)  3  (CF  3  CH  2  OH)  2  ](CB  11  H  12  ) (10). CTV (5.8, 0.013 mmol) and cesium carborane (1.6 mg, 0.006 mmol) were dissolved separately in hot 2,2,2-trifluoroethanol and mixed, and an excess of 0.1 M aqueous NaOH (0.1 mL) was added. The solution was cooled and allowed to stand. Colorless prismatic crystals of Na(CTV)2(DMF)2(H2O)3(CF3CH2OH) (10) appeared after 1 day, which lose solvent on standing.
